beginning.prompt: Beginning of a subsequence in your sequence (-b)

format.python: ( "" , " -b " + str( value ) )[ value is not None ]

beginning.comment: <text lang="en">Select the beginning of a subsequence from a larger sequence file. The smallest sequence that tacg can handle is 4 bases, 10 for the ladders map (-l). This allows analysis of primers and linkers.</text> </comment>

end.prompt: End of a subsequence in your sequence (-e)

format.python: ( "" , " -f " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

degeneracy.prompt: Degeneracy flag - controls input and analysis of degenerate sequence input (-D)

authorized_values.label: FORCES exclusion of degens in sequence; only 'acgtu' accepted (0)
Cut as NONdegen unless degen's found; then cut as '-D3' (1)
Degen's OK; ignore in KEY, but match outside of KEY (2)
Degen's OK; expand in KEY, find only EXACT matches (3)
Degen's OK; expand in KEY, find ALL POSSIBLE matches (4)

format.python: ( "" , " -D " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

degeneracy.comment: <text lang="en">The pattern matching is adaptive; given a small window of nondegenerate sequence, the algorithm will match very fast; if degenerate sequence is detected, it will switch to a slower, iterative approach. This results in speed that is proportional to degeneracy for most cases. </text> </comment>

codon.prompt: Codon Usage table to use for translation (-C)

authorized_values.label: Mold, Protozoan, and Coelenterate Mitochondrial and the Mycoplasma/Spiroplasma (3)

format.python: ( "" , " -C " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

order_by_cut.prompt: Order the output by number of cuts/fragments (-c)

precond.python: print_fragments != 0 or sites  or ladder_map  or gel_map

format.python: ( "" , " -w " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

width.comment: <text lang="en">The number is truncated to a # exactly divisible by 15 (-w 100 will be interpreted as -w 90) and actual printed output will be about 20 characters wider. Also applies to output of the ladder and gel maps, so if you are trying to get more accuracy and your output device can display small fonts, you may want to use this flag to widen the output. </text> </comment>

format.python: ( "" , " -G" + str(binsize) +"," + str(value) )[ value is not None ]

binsize.comment: <text lang="en">N bases for which hits should be pooled (integer)</text> </comment>

authorized_values.label: ID line and normal output regardless of hits (0)
BOTH ID line and normal output are printed ONLY IF there are hits (1)
ONLY ID line is  printed  if there are hits (2)

format.python: ( "" , " -i " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

idonly.comment: <text lang="en">Controls the output for sequences (in a collection) that have no hits for the options selected.</text> </comment>

max_cut.prompt: Maximum number of cuts allowed in sequence (-M)

min_cut.prompt: Minimum number of cuts in sequence for the enzyme to be selected (-m)

magnitude.prompt: Select enzymes by magnitude of recognition site (-n)

format.python: ( "" , " -n " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

magnitude.comment: <text lang="en">The 'magnitude' of the recognition sequence depends on the number of defined bases that make up the site. Degenerate bases can also contribute:</text> <text lang="en">acgt each count '1' magnitude point</text> <text lang="en">yrwsmk each count '1/2' magnitude point</text> <text lang="en">bdhu each count '1/4' magnitude point</text> <text lang="en">n doesn't count at all</text> <text lang="en">Those enzymes sequences' patterns that 'sum' to the equivalent of at least the given magnitude pass the test</text> <text lang="en">The values are upwardly inclusive (5=5,6,7,8 6=6,7,8 ...)</text> </comment>

format.python: ( "" , " -o " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

summary.comment: <text lang="en">Prints the summary of site information, describing how many times each pattern matches the sequence. Those that match zero times are shown first. In Ver >2, only those that match at least once are shown in the second part (the 0 matchers are not reiterated) </text> </comment>

authorized_values.label: Fragments printed in order of generation (unsorted) (1)
Fragments sorted by size, smallest to largest (2)

format.python: ( "" , " -F " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

ladder_map.comment: <text lang="en">Specify if you want a ladder map of selected enzymes, much like the GCG MAPPLOT output. Also appends a summary of those enzymes that match a few times. The number of matches that is included in the summary is length-sensitive in the distributed source code.</text> </comment>

cutoff.comment: <text lang="en">You can cut off any size in 10^n increments (as you might want to cut off very large fragments if you were doing chromosomal digests).</text> </comment>

linear_map.prompt: Specify if you want linear map (-L)
linear_map.comment: <text lang="en">This spews the most output (about 10x the # of input characters) and depending on what other options are specified, can be of moderate to very little use. If you want the co-translation, you'll have to specify it via the -T flag below. The Linear map also no longer shows ALL the patterns that match from the pattern file. It now obeys the same filtering rules that the Sites, Fragments, Ladder Map and other analyses do. </text> </comment>

precond.python: linear_map  and three_letter is not None and translation_frames is not None

translation.comment: <text lang="en">Requests frames 1, 1-3, or 1-6 to be cotranslated with the Linear Map using 1 or 3 letter codes.</text> </comment>

precond.python: frame is not None and min_size is not None
Name is not None  and pattern is not None and errors is not None
nameA is not None and distance is not None and nameB is not None

proximity.comment: <text lang="en">Use this option to search for spacial relationships between factors, 2 at a time (up to a total of 10).</text> </comment>

distance.comment: <text lang="en">Distance specification: [+-][lg]Dist_Lo[-Dist_Hi</text> <text lang="en">+ NameA is DOWNSTREAM of NameB (default is either)</text> <text lang="en">- NameA is UPSTREAM of NameB (ditto)</text> <text lang="en">l NameA is LESS THAN Dist_Lo from NameB (default)</text> <text lang="en">g NameA is GREATER THAN Dist_Lo from NameB</text> </comment>

nameA.comment: <text lang="en">NameA must be enzymes names (Rebase db)</text> </comment>

nameB.comment: <text lang="en">NameB must be enzymes names (Rebase db)</text> </comment>

comment: <text lang="en">smile is a program that was primarily made to extract promoter sequences from sequences. The interest of this program is to infer simultaneously several motifs (calledboxes) that respects distance constraints. The user has to select criterias. In a first step of extraction, all signals respecting these criterias are found. In a second step, they are all statistically evaluated, aiming to detect the ones that are exceptionally represented in the original sequences.</text> </comment>
